dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey, so I was just reading this, uh, fascinating report out of Israel...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey, so I was just reading this, uh, fascinating report out of Israel...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, you mean the one about Pfizer's vaccine? That's, like, huge news, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, you mean the one about Pfizer's vaccine? That's, like, huge news, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly! I mean, they're saying it's staving off illness and death for over 95% of patients. That's, um, pretty incredible.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly! I mean, they're saying it's staving off illness and death for over ninety five percent of patients. That's, um, pretty incredible.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Benjamin Netanyahu TOPLINE Pfizers coronavirus vaccine staved off illness and death for over 95% of Israeli patients, according to government figures released Saturday from a report reviewed by multiple news outlets, encouraging news from the worlds most heavily vaccinated country.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely! And the Ministry of Health there, they looked at like 1.7 million fully vaccinated Israelis. So it's not, you know, a small sample size.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely! And the Ministry of Health there, they looked at like one point seven million fully vaccinated Israelis. So it's not, you know, a small sample size.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Israels Ministry of Health studied the roughly 1.7 million Israelis who had received both shots of Pfizers vaccine as of the end of last month, and released a report later obtained by Reuters and several local news outlets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Right! And the numbers are just wild. Like, 95.8% less likely to get sick, and almost 99% less likely to be hospitalized or die. Wow.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right! And the numbers are just wild. Like, ninety five point eight percent less likely to get sick, and almost ninety nine percent less likely to be hospitalized or die. Wow.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Two weeks after receiving both doses, vaccinated Israelis were 95.8% less likely to fall ill from Covid-19 and 98.9% less likely to face hospitalization or death, Reuters reported.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's not just that one study. Their main healthcare provider also found vaccinated people are 92% less likely to have serious COVID cases.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's not just that one study. Their main healthcare provider also found vaccinated people are ninety two percent less likely to have serious C O V I D cases.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The countrys main healthcare provider said Sunday vaccinated patients are 92% less likely to end up with serious Covid-19 cases than their unvaccinated peers

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It really shows why they're leading the world, huh? They're like, what, 32% fully vaccinated now?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really shows why they're leading the world, huh? They're like, what, thirty two percent fully vaccinated now?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: 32.4%. Thats the share of Israelis who are fully vaccinated as of Saturday, according to the New York Times tracker.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, way ahead of, uh, most countries, including the US at, like, 5%. It's partly because they're small, I guess, and really efficient with their HMOs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, way ahead of, uh, most countries, including the U S at, like, five percent. It's partly because they're small, I guess, and really efficient with their H M Os.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The country ranks first in the world for vaccinations, compared to the United States 5.1% immunization rate. KEY BACKGROUND Israel is leading the worldwide vaccination race, partly due to the countrys small size, speed in buying up doses and comprehensive network of HMOs

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And everyone's watching them, right? Fauci even called it a "remarkable diminution in cases."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And everyone's watching them, right? Fauci even called it a remarkable diminution in cases.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Israel has a remarkable diminution in cases associated with the efficiency of their vaccine, U.S. infectious disease expert Dr. Anthony Fauci said Wednesday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they're essentially the world's biggest test case for mass vaccination. And, um, it seems to be working, with cases and hospitalizations declining.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they're essentially the world's biggest test case for mass vaccination. And, um, it seems to be working, with cases and hospitalizations declining.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Public health authorities around the world are watching Israels progress closely, making the country the planets largest test case for the impact of mass-vaccination. So far, experts say theres reason for cautious optimism: cases and hospitalizations have declined for several weeks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, what does this mean for them, like, getting back to normal?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what does this mean for them, like, getting back to normal?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, that's the interesting part! They're planning a partial return to normalcy next week, but *only* for those who are immunized.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, that's the interesting part! They're planning a partial return to normalcy next week, but only for those who are immunized.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Buoyed by a high vaccination rate, Israel is planning a partial return to normalcy next week but only for those who have been immunized.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, so like, a 'green pass' to get into gyms and restaurants? That's, uh, pretty significant.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, so like, a green pass to get into gyms and restaurants? That's, uh, pretty significant.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the coming weeks, residents who have received both Pfizer shots will get access to gyms, restaurants and bars, while those who cant prove vaccination or prior Covid-19 infection will need to stay away from nonessential places.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. If you can prove you're vaccinated or had a prior infection, you're in. Otherwise, you're staying home from non-essential places.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. If you can prove you're vaccinated or had a prior infection, you're in. Otherwise, you're staying home from non-essential places.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the coming weeks, residents who have received both Pfizer shots will get access to gyms, restaurants and bars, while those who cant prove vaccination or prior Covid-19 infection will need to stay away from nonessential places.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's a pretty strong incentive. But, um, what about these new variants? Is that still a concern?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's a pretty strong incentive. But, um, what about these new variants? Is that still a concern?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's the big 'watch out' still. Researchers are studying it. Some drugmakers are saying their vaccines are a *little* less effective against, say, the South African variant, but still offer protection.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's the big watch out still. Researchers are studying it. Some drugmakers are saying their vaccines are a little less effective against, say, the South African variant, but still offer protection.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Researchers are still studying whether new coronavirus mutations could blunt vaccines effectiveness. Most drugmakers including Pfizer, Moderna, Johnson & Johnson and Novavax say their vaccine candidates are somewhat less effective at staving off the virus variant rapidly spreading in South Africa, though they still offer patients some protection.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] So, booster shots are probably on the horizon then?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, booster shots are probably on the horizon then?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As a result, several companies are working on booster shots to combat emerging new strains.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. Companies are already working on them for those emerging strains. So, uh, cautious optimism seems to be the vibe.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. Companies are already working on them for those emerging strains. So, uh, cautious optimism seems to be the vibe.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As a result, several companies are working on booster shots to combat emerging new strains.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: C-cautious optimism. I can get behind that. It's good to see some really strong data coming out, though.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: C-cautious optimism. I can get behind that. It's good to see some really strong data coming out, though.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. A glimmer of hope, I'd say.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. A glimmer of hope, I'd say.
